title: 108_hr1079
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the Short Title. It includes Increased Expensing for Small Business. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, such as increasing the dollar limitation for aggregate costs to $75,000 and the phaseout threshold to $325,000. Additionally, certain computer software is defined as section 179 property. The phaseout threshold for section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is increased to $325,000. Section 179 property now includes tangible property and computer software described in section 197(e)(3)(A)(i) to which section 167 applies. The phaseout threshold for section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is increased to $325,000. Section 179 property now includes tangible property and computer software described in section 197(e)(3)(A)(i) to which section 167 applies. The term does not include property described in section 50(b) or air conditioning/heating units. Inflation adjustments are made for taxable years. Inflation adjustments are made for taxable years beginning in a calendar year after 2003. Dollar amounts in section 179 are increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. The cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years beginning after 2003 increases dollar amounts in section 179. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000 or $10,000 as necessary. The cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years beginning after 2003 increases dollar amounts in section 179. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000 or $10,000 as necessary. The taxpayer may revoke an election under paragraph (1) with respect to any property, and once made, the revocation shall be irrevocable. The taxpayer can revoke an election under paragraph (1) regarding any property, and once revoked, it is irrevocable. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Neutral cost recovery depreciation adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. Deduction adjustment to allow equivalent of expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003, under Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction adjustment allows for the equivalent of expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003, under Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is determined for each taxable year after the property is placed in service. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the corresponding calendar quarter by the gross domestic product. The neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service is calculated by multiplying the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The neutral cost recovery ratio is determined by multiplying the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The ratio shall never be less than 1 and is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is determined based on the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service. It shall never be less than 1 and is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. The implicit price deflator for the gross domestic product in a calendar quarter is used to determine the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service. Taxpayers can elect not to have this subsection apply to their property, and churning transactions may exempt property from this section. The additional deduction under this section does not affect the property's basis or recapture. The additional deduction under this section does not impact the adjusted basis of property or interests in pass-thru entities, and it is not considered a depreciation deduction for certain tax purposes. Pass-thru entities include regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, and partnerships. The term 'pass-thru entity' includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. Minimum tax treatment for property under section 168(k) after December 31, 2003, allows for a deduction using a neutral cost recovery ratio. The new subparagraph allows for a deduction using a neutral cost recovery ratio for property under section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003. The new subparagraph allows for a deduction using a neutral cost recovery ratio for property under section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003. Subparagraph (C) of section 56(g)(4) is amended to exclude the additional deduction allowable by section 168(k). Coordination with the depreciation limitation on certain automobiles is also addressed in section 280F(a)(1)(B) of the Code. The amendment allows for a neutral cost recovery deduction under section 168(k) for property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The unrecovered basis of passenger automobiles includes the additional amount determined under section 168(k) not allowed as a deduction. Effective date for these amendments is for taxable years ending after December 31, 2003.
